commit_message:
DRAFT: Enable cross-process communication in the Data Services Engine

Currently, Congress data source and policy engine modules must reside
in a GreenThread in the same Python process. We aim to refactor the
data services engine (DSE) messaging wrapper to enable cross-process
messaging. The oslo.messaging framework will be used to facilitate
module communication.

blueprint dist-cross-project-dse

Change-Id: I1200f71da220d53e4ea24b6ae513352e33c92f6b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress-specs refs/changes/93/214893/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================= Cross Process DSE ================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/congress/+spec/cross-process-dse Update the Congress Data Services Engine (DSE) to support services spanning multiple processes and/or systems. The existing policy engine, data sources, and API will be refactored to leverage the new framework. Problem description =================== Congress is composed of multiple services responsible for sourcing data, computing policy, and executing actions. Services communicate with each other using the DSE framework. It is desirable to split services across multiple processes and/or systems to meet scalability and high available requirements. The DSE, however, does not currently support service communication outside of a single Python process. The DSE should be enhanced to meet the following properties: * Support service communication between multiple processes on the same host or spanning multiple hosts. * For this design, we expect common deployment scenarios to require between 4 and 16 services. * Each process may connect or disconnect at any time due to an administrative action or environmental fault. * Each service must observe a single, eventually-consistent view of data on the DSE. * A common directory of data services and their exported tables must be published to all services on the DSE. * Story: An API service needs to expose available data to the user. * Story: A policy service needs to validate new policy rules follow schemas of available tables. * Services may dynamically subscribe to tables exposed by other services. * Story: A user adds a policy to a policy engine service. The policy engine service must subscribe to tables referenced in the new policy so it can maintain a current view of data for policy computation. * Services may dynamically update which tables they export. * Story: A user adds a policy statement creating a new table. A audit service subscribes to the table, forwarding all changes to a security event manager tool. * Table updates are expected to be low-volume: * Data update frequency: 1/second/service * Average data update size: < 100 kB * Maximum data update size: 1 MB * Total data size is expected to be small enough to fit in RAM of each process participating on the DSE. * Common OpenStack patterns and libraries should be used where appropriate. Proposed change =============== * The DSE will be updated to leverage oslo.messaging RPC for communication between processes. * Each service will run in its own process * We may enable multiple services in a single process in the future, if the need arises. * The API will participate on the DSE, and will run in its own process * A base DseNode class will be created to implement common DSE operations: * Control channel: each node will pass control messages on a unique topic to communicate node status and health to other nodes. * Node RPC: directly invoke a method on a named node TODO(pballand): additional structure to be filled in Alternatives ------------ We discussed several potential designs during the Congress mid-cycle sprint: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/congress-liberty-sprint Policy ------ None Policy actions -------------- None Data sources ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- N/A REST API impact --------------- The majority of APIs will remain unchanged, however the change to one service per process will cause service management APIs to become read-only. Security impact --------------- Congress computes policy based on data from across systems in the data center, which may be sensitive. Transporting this data across a message bus increases the exposure of the data. This increased risk can be mitigated by following best practices to secure the message bus and its communication channels. Notifications impact -------------------- N/A Other end user impact --------------------- N/A Performance impact ------------------ Message passing via a bus will have associated bandwidth and latency penalties when compared to in-process calls. The magnitude of the impact depends of many factors. In this design, we focus on the architectural elements only, leaving optimizations of the mechanics (e.g., serialization formats) for later study. Other deployer impact --------------------- This change adds an external message bus dependency to Congress. Many OpenStack projects already share this dependency. The administrator will need to manage multiple processes for running Congress. A separate config file will be used for each process. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: pballand Other contributors: sayaji15 Work items ---------- TBD Dependencies ============ * oslo.messagaing Testing ======= TBD Documentation impact ==================== None References ========== https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/congress-liberty-sprint

commit_message:
Add insecure_registry column to baymoddel

Adding new column of `insecure_registry`, it indicates using insecure
registry when deploying a bay, it should be a validate url with port.

Partially-Implements: blueprint support-insecure-registry
Change-Id: Iaa28d6409264d1d2acd992a7fa14630bb6394852

subject: Update Magnum service name and description
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-20 15:01:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/magnum/commit/721a17eeed4b17de111f72f4224260a5f4fc1882', 'message': 'Update Magnum service name and description

After this patch [1], Magnum is no longer a container service. It

commit_message:
Update Magnum service name and description

After this patch [1], Magnum is no longer the "Container Service", it
became the "Container Infrastructure Management Service". This commit
updates the service name and description accordingly:
* Change service name from "container" to "container-infra"
* Update service description to reflect its mission

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/311476/

Depends-On: I55205ff2b304678d2b53bbd4d66403078c6baac8
Closes-Bug: #1584251
Change-Id: I5c271bf3fc4d6ccecaf2918aca28ce946bcc6b22
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/00/319300/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: service_type='container-infra',

Remove wsgi functionality

Since oslo.service contains wsgi functionality we can remove it from nova.

commit_message:
Refactor get_filtered_hosts in filter host manager

* Linearized control flow
* Removed nested functions

Change-Id: Id1580348d4c2ff23d750363fa9a03576080c88c0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/78/192878/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: filters = self._choose_host_filters(filter_class_names) \ if filter_class_names else self.default_filters ignore_hosts = set(filter_properties.get('ignore_hosts', [])) force_hosts = set(filter_properties.get('force_hosts', [])) force_nodes = set(filter_properties.get('force_nodes', [])) # Filter out ignored hosts filtered_hosts = [host for host in hosts if host.host not in ignore_hosts] # Log valid hosts that were ignored in this filter ignored_hosts_str = ', '.join(host.host for host in set(hosts) - set(filtered_hosts)) msg = _('Host filter ignoring hosts: %s') LOG.info(msg % ignored_hosts_str) # Force scheduler to select designated hosts filtered_hosts = [host for host in filtered_hosts if not force_hosts or host.host in force_hosts] # Log hosts that were retained in this filter if filtered_hosts: forced_hosts_str = ', '.join(host.host for host in filtered_hosts) msg = _('Host filter forcing available hosts to %s') else: forced_hosts_str = ', '.join(force_hosts) msg = _("No hosts matched due to not matching " "'force_hosts' value of '%s'") LOG.info(msg % forced_hosts_str) # Force scheduler to select designated nodes # NOTE(deva): allow force_hosts and force_nodes independently filtered_hosts = [host for host in filtered_hosts if not force_nodes or host.nodename in force_nodes] # Log hosts that were retained in this filter if filtered_hosts: forced_nodes_str = ', '.join(host.nodename for host in filtered_hosts) msg = _('Host filter forcing available nodes to %s') else: forced_nodes_str = ', '.join(force_nodes) msg = _("No nodes matched due to not matching " "'force_nodes' value of '%s'") LOG.info(msg % forced_nodes_str) if force_hosts or force_nodes or not filtered_hosts: # NOTE(deva): Skip filters when forcing host or node return filtered_hosts else: return self.filter_handler.get_filtered_objects(filters, filtered_hosts, filter_properties, index)
deleted_lines: def _strip_ignore_hosts(host_map, hosts_to_ignore): ignored_hosts = [] for host in hosts_to_ignore: for (hostname, nodename) in host_map.keys(): if host == hostname: del host_map[(hostname, nodename)] ignored_hosts.append(host) ignored_hosts_str = ', '.join(ignored_hosts) msg = _('Host filter ignoring hosts: %s') LOG.info(msg % ignored_hosts_str) def _match_forced_hosts(host_map, hosts_to_force): forced_hosts = [] for (hostname, nodename) in host_map.keys(): if hostname not in hosts_to_force: del host_map[(hostname, nodename)] else: forced_hosts.append(hostname) if host_map: forced_hosts_str = ', '.join(forced_hosts) msg = _('Host filter forcing available hosts to %s') else: forced_hosts_str = ', '.join(hosts_to_force) msg = _("No hosts matched due to not matching " "'force_hosts' value of '%s'") LOG.info(msg % forced_hosts_str) def _match_forced_nodes(host_map, nodes_to_force): forced_nodes = [] for (hostname, nodename) in host_map.keys(): if nodename not in nodes_to_force: del host_map[(hostname, nodename)] else: forced_nodes.append(nodename) if host_map: forced_nodes_str = ', '.join(forced_nodes) msg = _('Host filter forcing available nodes to %s') else: forced_nodes_str = ', '.join(nodes_to_force) msg = _("No nodes matched due to not matching " "'force_nodes' value of '%s'") LOG.info(msg % forced_nodes_str) if filter_class_names is None: filters = self.default_filters else: filters = self._choose_host_filters(filter_class_names) ignore_hosts = filter_properties.get('ignore_hosts', []) force_hosts = filter_properties.get('force_hosts', []) force_nodes = filter_properties.get('force_nodes', []) if ignore_hosts or force_hosts or force_nodes: # NOTE(deva): we can't assume "host" is unique because # one host may have many nodes. name_to_cls_map = {(x.host, x.nodename): x for x in hosts} if ignore_hosts: _strip_ignore_hosts(name_to_cls_map, ignore_hosts) if not name_to_cls_map: return [] # NOTE(deva): allow force_hosts and force_nodes independently if force_hosts: _match_forced_hosts(name_to_cls_map, force_hosts) if force_nodes: _match_forced_nodes(name_to_cls_map, force_nodes) if force_hosts or force_nodes: # NOTE(deva): Skip filters when forcing host or node if name_to_cls_map: return name_to_cls_map.values() hosts = six.itervalues(name_to_cls_map) return self.filter_handler.get_filtered_objects(filters, hosts, filter_properties, index)

commit_message:
Scale-instance: Scale virtual CPUs and memory of live instances

Phase(I): Scale cpu/memory of instances without guest numa architecture
Phase(II): Scale cpu/memory of instances with defined guest numa architecture
Phase(III): Live migrate if local compute node does not have enough resources

NOTE: This patch is not currently intended to be merged.
Instead, this patch intends to just demonstrate feasibility of Phase(I)
and provide an indication on feature complexity.

Change-Id: I04b0db1dc04e68ee469ed7fb385a13d4def27973

added_lines: @utils.synchronized(COMPUTE_RESOURCE_SEMAPHORE) def scale_claim(self, context, instance, instance_type, deltas, limits): """Indicate that resources are needed for a scale operation to this compute host. :param context: security context :param instance: instance object to reserve resources for :param instance_type: current instance_type :param deltas: requested resources deltas :param limits: Dict of oversubscription limits for memory, disk, and CPUs :returns: A Claim ticket representing the reserved resources. This should be turned into finalize a resource claim or free resources after the compute operation is finished. """ # compute_driver doesn't support resource tracking, # continue scale operation. if self.disabled: return claims.NopClaim() instance_ref = obj_base.obj_to_primitive(instance) usage = self._calc_usage_for_scale(context, instance, limits, instance_type, deltas) claim = claims.ScaleClaim(context, instance_ref, usage, self, self.compute_node, limits=limits) self._update_usage(context, self.compute_node, usage) self._update(context.elevated(), self.compute_node) return claim @utils.synchronized(COMPUTE_RESOURCE_SEMAPHORE) def drop_scale_claim(self, context, instance, usage): """Indicate to resource tracker that associated resources with scale operation are no longer in usage. """ self._update_usage(context, self.compute_node, usage, sign=-1) self._update(context.elevated(), self.compute_node) def _calc_usage_for_scale(self, context, instance, resources, instance_type, deltas): """Calculates usage for scale instance operation.""" usage = dict() usage['memory_mb'] = deltas['ram'] usage['vcpus'] = deltas['cores'] return usage

commit_message:
Add oslo_config PortOpt support

As oslo_config profides PortOpt type to validate the range of port
now, we could change port to PortOpt from IntOpt.

Change-Id: I341f679e939f7c2fedf937bba971c36cd603b752

commit_message:
Implement custom header support for Octavia

Implements support for custom header insertion in Octavia.
A listener may be configured to insert custom headers which are
supported by Octavia. Currently implemented support for
X-Forwarded-For header, and X-Forwarded-Port

Change-Id: I784f4939225c3acef362fcb5df57e77dbfb0f774

subject: VMware: anti-affinity placement scheduling for cluster
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-09 10:20:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2aeb9d2dc625d0f3f1452c0ec73fc165d917a18d', 'message': "WIP: VMware: change ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter filter behavior for vmware

A cluster in vcenter is exposed as a compute node on nova.
There can be a maximum of 64 hosts per cluster.
Currently, for an instance/server group, ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter
would schedule only one instance per cluster. The maximum number of
instances from a server group can only be equal to number of
clusters/compute nodes.

This patch adds capability 'resource_scheduling' and used in
scheduler filters.
ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter behavior is modified
such that if the driver+host has 'resource_scheduling' capabilities
then select the host and pass the anti-affinity placement to be done
done by vcenter. This change would allow deploying more instances within a
cluster. Also, since the actual state of DRS is queried, vm placement based
on affinity rules is guaranteed.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I03cc9c53c75feea8287d4354c7562d398134e0b8
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-11-04 08:48:12.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py', 'nova/virt/fake.py', 'nova/virt/vmwareapi/driver.py', 'nova/scheduler/filters/affinity_filter.py', 'nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute.py', 'nova/virt/driver.py', 'nova/tests/unit/scheduler/filters/test_affinity_filters.py', 'nova/compute/manager.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2d91bfb68cbe7b06ab48593b9f7c9ec62cf3b4a0', 'message': "VMware: anti-affinity placement scheduling for cluster

This patch adds a new capability 'resource_scheduling' and used in

done by vcenter [1].

[1] http://tinyurl.com/qfyc6t8

Change-Id: I03cc9c53c75feea8287d4354c7562d398134e0b8
"}]
commit_message:
VMware: anti-affinity placement scheduling for cluster

A cluster in vcenter is exposed as a compute node on nova.
There can be a maximum of 64 hosts per cluster.
Currently, for an instance/server group, ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter
would schedule only one instance per cluster. The maximum number of
instances from a server group can only be equal to number of
clusters/compute nodes.

This patch adds a new capability 'resource_scheduling' and used in
scheduler filters.
ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter behavior is fixed
such that if the driver+host has 'resource_scheduling' capabilities
then select the host and pass the anti-affinity placement to be done
done by vcenter [1].
This change would allow deploying more instances within a cluster.

[1] http://tinyurl.com/qfyc6t8

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint vmware-placement-policy

Change-Id: I03cc9c53c75feea8287d4354c7562d398134e0b8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/12/210812/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if 'anti-affinity' not in group.policies: return resource_scheduling = self.driver.capabilities.get( 'resource_scheduling', False) group_hosts = group.get_hosts(exclude=[instance.uuid]) if self.host in group_hosts and not resource_scheduling: msg = _("Anti-affinity instance group policy was violated.") raise exception.RescheduledException( instance_uuid=instance.uuid, reason=msg)
deleted_lines: if 'anti-affinity' in group.policies: group_hosts = group.get_hosts(exclude=[instance.uuid]) if self.host in group_hosts: msg = _("Anti-affinity instance group policy " "was violated.") raise exception.RescheduledException( instance_uuid=instance.uuid, reason=msg)

commit_message:
*Nova can incorrectly think an instance is volume backed
if instance is booted with "nova boot...",it confuses api.py &
assume if image_ref isn't set then theinstance is volume backed.
closes Bug: #1501851

Change-Id: I1aace00479274d20435b178aa8f6e425ad9b6e9f

commit_message:
WIP: db-specific changes related to resource providers blueprint.
Added ResourceClass, ResourceProvider, ResourcePool,
HostAggregateResourcePool, Inventory and Allocation classes into
model. Added appropriate migration files. Added uuid field to
compute_nodes table and filled it in with uuid4 values.

Change-Id: I39730cfb80d6fcbfb02c177ed086d7da243c5e9d
Implements: blueprint resource-providers

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-28 16:36:49.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/ironic/driver.py', 'nova/tests/unit/virt/ironic/test_driver.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/4e2386784750c8581af53f11e729545a99913408', 'message': 'Ironic: Do not wait for the node to be unprovisioned

commit_message:
Ironic: Do not wait for the node to be unprovisioned

Ironic will now allow a deployment to be interrupted at any stage. But
for some states where it can not be immediately stopped Ironic will just
mark that node and the unprovisioning will be deferred to later.

This patch patch then:

1) Allows unprovision to be called when the node is at DEPLOYING state
(which was not possible to be interrupted before)

2) Do not loop and pool the node being unprovisioned, Ironic will take
care of tearing the node down when possible.

Closes-Bug: #1477490
Related blueprint lazy-delete-instances
Change-Id: I996b2970992995e27dc03af6109481e4a20df15a

subject: libvirt live-migration: Monitoring task tracks progress watermark incorrectly
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-24 19:25:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2963f1c92aeee8f28736f14e640afc4ec8214e74', 'message': 'libvirt live-migration: Monitoring task does not track progress watermark

It is possible for a libvirt to report libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_UNBOUNDED

commit_message:
libvirt live-migration: Monitoring task tracks progress watermark incorrectly

It is possible for a libvirt to report libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_UNBOUNDED
in _live_migration_monitor but return 0s for data_remaining, which in
turn makes out progress watermark 0 which is lower than it is likely to
get during the migration and basically useless to report as it is going to be 0.

This patch checks to ensure that data_remaining is greater than 0
prior to setting the progress_watermark value when libvirt reports
libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_UNBOUNDED.

Change-Id: Ic38ad783a0ed6ecce9bac903eafde3c7e243f791
Closes-Bug: #1499449

commit_message:
Add support for yfs storage protocol

The cinder driver for Daowoo YeeSan(bp: cinder-driver-for-yeesan)
introduces a new storage protocol `yfs`. This protocol currently only
support libvirt and qemu. This patch add a new volume driver to
support yfs protocol for libvirt.

Implements: blueprint support-yfs-storage-protocol
Change-Id: I3cc12f745c8db08673d45f4642d4f097b1f7ad82
Depends-On: I6a3d2290ac326f24257af663c014596c4cf842a9

commit_message:
Fix order of arguments in assertEqual

Some tests used incorrect order assertEqual(observed, expected).

The correct order expected by testtools is
assertEqual(expected, observed).

Partial-Bug: #1259292

subject: VMware: Append disk type to image cache folder name
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-24 04:10:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/fddca17ce0f7cf022d9bf7c5972de98fae4b9b3c', 'message': 'VMware: Append disk type to image cache folder name

When spawning a new instance, vmware driver creates
and caches vmdk from glance image. For any new instances
based on same image, it reuses the cached vmdk as source.

Even when the disk type (preallocated, streamOptimized, sparse)
of the image is updated on glance, nova continues to use the

In this patch, the image cache folder name on nova is appended

commit_message:
VMware: Append disk type to image cache folder name

When spawning a new instance, vmware driver creates
and caches vmdk from glance image. For any new instances
based on same image, it reuses the cached vmdk as source.

Even when the disk type (preallocated, streamOptimized, sparse)
of the image is updated on glance, nova continues to use the
same cached image file.
This causes issue reported in bug #1339342.

In this patch, the image cache folder name on nova is appended
with disk type such that a new image corresponding to disk type
is created and cached.

Change-Id: I96eec4389bb8c9f5f3141d04f628c34b7fe00419
Closes-Bug: #1339342
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/04/227104/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: def get_image_cache_folder(self, datastore, image_id): return datastore.build_path(self._base_folder, image_id)

commit_message:
WIP: Allow admin to reboot instances when syncing power states

This re-uses a config option to allow the admin to decide
what should happen when syncing instance power states and nova
thinks the instance is stopped but the hypervisor says it's not.

This is backwards compatible since resume_guests_state_on_host_boot
defaults to False. By rebooting the instance, it will align the
nova database and the hypervisor states.

UpgradeImpact: The resume_guests_state_on_host_boot config option
will now also reboot instances during the _sync_power_states periodic
task.

Change-Id: Ibfd3a1a49c6b9e71af695f09b5bc8690ff31da97
Closes-Bug: #1463688
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/75/218975/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Current vm_state: " "%(vm_state)s, current task_state: " "%(task_state)s, original DB power_state: " "%(db_power_state)s, current VM power_state: " "%(vm_power_state)s"), if (vm_power_state == RUNNING and CONF.resume_guests_state_on_host_boot): LOG.warning(_LW('Rebooting the instance to sync up ' 'the nova-compute service with the ' 'hypervisor.'), instance=db_instance) # We have to do a hard reboot since the reboot API # won't allow a soft reboot on a "stopped" instance. self.compute_api.reboot(context, db_instance, 'HARD') else: # NOTE(russellb) Force the stop, because normally the # compute API would not allow an attempt to stop a stopped # instance. LOG.warning(_LW('Calling the stop API.'), instance=db_instance) self.compute_api.force_stop(context, db_instance)

commit_message:
Use the oslo.utils.reflection to extract the class name

The oslo.utils reflection module/code handles more variations
of where a class name may come from (on python 2 and python 3)
so its usage allows getting more accurate class names so we might
as well use it.

Change-Id: I625711cd366f6ca355e87f4d5602854aa9de191c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/43/224843/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_utils import reflection cls_name = reflection.get_class_name(filter_, fully_qualified=False)

commit_message:
Promoting SPICE vm performance(video, sound and other)

Now, More and more enterprises use OpenStack as Desktop Virtualization Platform, it need improving remote display performance and playing music/sound files.
So, this blueprint hope improving display performance and supporting audio in Spice client.

spice channel, (document addr: http://www.libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementCharChannel)
In short, it is a virtual serial port channel, to optimize some communication between the host and virtual machine.
After power up virtual machine, you will find some unknown devices in device manager.
we should install drivers for these devices (drivers download addr is http://www.spice-space.org/download/windows/spice-guest-tools/) .
These drivers contain whole virtual graphics card driver, virtual network card driver and virtual serial port card driver.
this corresponds to the following libvirt XML:
<channel type='spicevmc'>
    <target type='virtio' name='com.redhat.spice.0'/>
      <alias name='virserial-channel1'/>
</channel>

video, this corresponds to the following libvirt XML:
<video>
  <model type='qxl'  vram='65536' heads='1'/>
</video>

sound, this corresponds to the following libvirt XML:
<sound  model='ich6'>
    <address type='pci'  domain='0x0000' bus='0x00' slot='0x04' function='0x0'/>
</sound>

Blueprint libvirt-spice-video-sound-driver

Change-Id: I0f1cec49f0da8a1f27f665cea8efd4e669435c1c

modify the code format!

Blueprint libvirt-spice-video-sound-driver

Change-Id: I0f1cec49f0da8a1f27f665cea8efd4e669435c1c

modify the code format!

Blueprint libvirt-spice-video-sound-driver

Change-Id: I0f1cec49f0da8a1f27f665cea8efd4e669435c1c

self).format_dom() dev.set("type", self.type) drv_target = etree.Element("target") drv_target.set("type", self.target_type) drv_target.set("name", self.target_name) dev.append(drv_target) drv_alias = etree.Element("alias") drv_alias.set("name", self.alias_name) dev.append(drv_alias) return dev class LibvirtConfigGuestVideo(LibvirtConfigGuestDevice): def __init__(self, **kwargs): super(LibvirtConfigGuestVideo, self).__init__(root_name="video", **kwargs) #self.type = "tablet" #self.bus = "usb" self.type = "qxl" self.vram = "65536" self.heads = "1" def format_dom(self): dev = self.model = "ich6" self.address_type = "pci" self.address_domain = "0x0000" self.address_bus = "0x00" self.address_slot = "0x04" self.address_function = "0x0" def format_dom(self): dev = self.address_domain) drv_address.set("bus", self.address_bus) drv_address.set("slot", self.address_slot) drv_address.set("function", self.address_function) dev.append(drv_address) return dev self.image_compression = "auto_glz" self.streaming_mode = "filter" drv_image = etree.Element("image") drv_image.set("compression", self.image_compression) dev.append(drv_image) drv_streaming = etree.Element("streaming") drv_streaming.set("mode", self.streaming_mode) dev.append(drv_streaming)

commit_message:
Add uuid into SecurityGroup database model

This commit adds the uuid field into SecurityGroup database model,
it would be used for sync the data for both nova-network and
neutron

Related to blueprint add-id-to-security-groups-for-server-show

Change-Id: I30f37d0481155b8165e75f8c0ba3e9fc26995a22

commit_message:
Fix order of arguments in assertEqual

Some tests used incorrect order assertEqual(observed, expected).

The correct order expected by testtools is
assertEqual(expected, observed).

Partial-Bug: #1259292
Change-Id: I1a776cf12e634731dda68165190427034cf62dda

commit_message:
Ephemeral block devices start at xvde for XenAPI

See "DEVICE_EPHEMERAL = '4'" in nova/virt/xenapi/vmops.py (where '4'
translates to 'xvde' in zero-based device numbering).

Change-Id: I2399e940c6719a2f71bd4a9d2c1b54318cec38d3

commit_message:
Fix full deploy CI

6926a86c3088f76e00397e58862070ba5e2851e6 broke full
deploy CI, because I forgot to run it before merging.

We also don't need full-minimal.sh and full-deploy.sh.
Keeping full-deploy.sh since it is consistent with
the other CI scripts.

Change-Id: I88deb44d4bec1f740d57ac523b6c1667713f90a1

report an error for hw:numa_nodes=0

This patch throws a new exception InvalidNUMANodesNumber
when booting an instance with a flavor
with NUMA nodes set to 0 (hw:numa_nodes=0)

Change-Id: I20d1655c6e8b681e19a59d7a4b80b3f7d32b952a
Closes-Bug: #1402709

commit_message:
Fix order of arguments in assertEqual

Some tests used incorrect order assertEqual(observed, expected).

The correct order expected by testtools is
assertEqual(expected, observed).

Partial-Bug: #1259292
Change-Id: Ieb6c89e66e9c53fe381bee6c61163401cb02f730

commit_message:
Object: Improve Instance _save_flavor

Currently, in instance save() function, we call all fields save handler,
self._save_$attrname(), so _save_flavor, _save_new_flavor and _save_old_flavor
will be called sequentially, since _save_new_flavor and _save_old_flavor
just call _save_flavor, so we don't need to call _save_new_flavor _save_old_flavor
after _save_flavor is called.

Change-Id: I30d960a7c4818963cb539202e9dcf8ec3e712141

commit_message:
Make evacuate update the migration object along the way

This makes evacuate pass the migration object from api to conductor to
compute so that the migration status and dest_host can be updated during
the process for better progress visibility.

Related to blueprint robustify-evacuate

Change-Id: Ic940ffe449e000535b55697a516ba5199a2d2d60

commit_message:
API support for migration_type

This adds microversion 2.5 which exposes the hidden and migration_type
fields in the migrations listing.

ApiImpact

Change-Id: I93cf54beb16051e1eab3bae1c3bf202579b7540f

subject: creating ordinary numa vm fails with large_page_vm
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-26 08:43:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2a537d66c5ceb180e31bda1d8275cae121c69bda', 'message': 'creating ordinary numa vm fails with large_page_vm

creating ordinary vm may fails with large page vm and ordinary vm on the
same numa node.

the following scene can reproduce the problem:
1. Assumpt that a host with two numa nodes are used to create vm, and the
memory of each numa node consists of 5GB huge page and 5GB ordinary page.

2. create a vm with huge page that use 3GB huge page memory in the host
numa node 0. Now, the usable memory of the host numa node 0 consists of
2GB huge page and 5GB ordinary page.

3. At this time, we create an ordinary numa vm with 6GB and the
NUMATopologyFilter filter may select the host numa node 0. If the host
numa node 0 is selected, the libvirt will report OOM error.

Change-Id: I6bc526b9b25cb7ebb7d1c8df60213d7e981f28c0
Closes-Bug:#1428551

commit_message:
creating ordinary numa vm fails with large_page_vm

creating ordinary vm may fails with large page vm and ordinary vm on the
same numa node.we can modify the ram_filter to using the ordinary memory
when creating the ordinary vm.

Change-Id: I6bc526b9b25cb7ebb7d1c8df60213d7e981f28c0
Closes-Bug:#1428551

commit_message:
Align the stars to bring our CI back alive

This patch squash 2 commits to bring our CI back:

1) Pin Tempest to latest working commit:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/297511/ broke us, we need to pin
Tempest to keep rolling.
This will be reverted once we sort things out.

2) rabbitmq: install packages from distro repos

Stop installing RabbitMQ from rabbitmq.com repository.

rabbitmq.com is providing a terrible and frustrating experience of
packaging repository:
* rabbitmq.com is very often down and we have to recheck our jobs
  everytime it happens.
* packaging signature is currently broken, see [1].

From this patch, we'll deploy RabbitMQ using distro repositories.

[1] https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppetlabs-rabbitmq/pull/476

Change-Id: I1e79c04d7cd796493ae56423b70626e8841cf284

commit_message:
Refactor UDP query handling, add tests

Change-Id: If4e18f50126089a1971ab3ba945b34f6774423dd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/27/311527/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import errnoimport struct # DNS packet with IQUERY opcode query_payload = binascii.a2b_hex( "271209000001000000000000076578616d706c6503636f6d0000010001" ) expected_response = binascii.a2b_hex( b"271289050001000000000000076578616d706c6503636f6d0000010001" ) # expected response is an error code REFUSED. The other fields are # id 10002 # opcode IQUERY # rcode REFUSED # flags QR RD # ;QUESTION # example.com. IN A # ;ANSWER # ;AUTHORITY # ;ADDITIONAL # Use self._print_dns_msg() to display the messages @staticmethod def _print_dns_msg(desc, wire): """Print DNS message for debugging""" q = dns.message.from_wire(wire).to_text() print("%s:\n%s\n" % (desc, q)) self.service._dns_handle_udp_query(self.addr, ' '.encode('utf-8')) self.service._dns_handle_udp_query(self.addr, self.query_payload) sendto_mock.assert_called_once_with(self.expected_response, self.addr) def test__dns_handle_tcp_conn_fail_unpack(self): # will call recv() only once mock_socket = mock.Mock() mock_socket.recv.side_effect = ['X', 'boo'] # X will fail unpack self.service._dns_handle_tcp_conn(('1.2.3.4', 42), mock_socket) self.assertEqual(1, mock_socket.recv.call_count) self.assertEqual(1, mock_socket.close.call_count) def test__dns_handle_tcp_conn_one_query(self): payload = self.query_payload mock_socket = mock.Mock() pay_len = struct.pack("!H", len(payload)) mock_socket.recv.side_effect = [pay_len, payload, socket.timeout] self.service._dns_handle_tcp_conn(('1.2.3.4', 42), mock_socket) self.assertEqual(3, mock_socket.recv.call_count) self.assertEqual(1, mock_socket.sendall.call_count) self.assertEqual(1, mock_socket.close.call_count) wire = mock_socket.sendall.call_args[0][0] expected_length_raw = wire[:2] (expected_length, ) = struct.unpack('!H', expected_length_raw) self.assertEqual(len(wire), expected_length + 2) self.assertEqual(self.expected_response, wire[2:]) def test__dns_handle_tcp_conn_multiple_queries(self): payload = self.query_payload mock_socket = mock.Mock() pay_len = struct.pack("!H", len(payload)) # Process 5 queries, than receive a misaligned query and close the # connection there mock_socket.recv.side_effect = [ pay_len, payload, pay_len, payload, pay_len, payload, pay_len, payload, pay_len, payload, 'X', payload, pay_len, payload, pay_len, payload, ] self.service._dns_handle_tcp_conn(('1.2.3.4', 42), mock_socket) self.assertEqual(11, mock_socket.recv.call_count) self.assertEqual(5, mock_socket.sendall.call_count) self.assertEqual(1, mock_socket.close.call_count) def test__dns_handle_tcp_conn_multiple_queries_socket_error(self): payload = self.query_payload mock_socket = mock.Mock() pay_len = struct.pack("!H", len(payload)) # Process 5 queries, than receive a socket error and close the # connection there mock_socket.recv.side_effect = [ pay_len, payload, pay_len, payload, pay_len, payload, pay_len, payload, pay_len, payload, socket.error(errno.EAGAIN), pay_len, payload, pay_len, payload, ] self.service._dns_handle_tcp_conn(('1.2.3.4', 42), mock_socket) self.assertEqual(11, mock_socket.recv.call_count) self.assertEqual(5, mock_socket.sendall.call_count) self.assertEqual(1, mock_socket.close.call_count) def test__dns_handle_tcp_conn_multiple_queries_ignore_bad_query(self): payload = self.query_payload mock_socket = mock.Mock() pay_len = struct.pack("!H", len(payload)) # Ignore a broken query and keep going as long as the query len # header was correct mock_socket.recv.side_effect = [ pay_len, payload, pay_len, payload[:-5] + 'hello', pay_len, payload, pay_len, payload, pay_len, payload, ] self.service._dns_handle_tcp_conn(('1.2.3.4', 42), mock_socket) self.assertEqual(11, mock_socket.recv.call_count) self.assertEqual(4, mock_socket.sendall.call_count) self.assertEqual(1, mock_socket.close.call_count)
deleted_lines: self.service._dns_handle(self.addr, ' '.encode('utf-8')) # DNS packet with IQUERY opcode payload = "271209000001000000000000076578616d706c6503636f6d0000010001" # expected response is an error code REFUSED. The other fields are # id 10002 # opcode IQUERY # rcode REFUSED # flags QR RD # ;QUESTION # example.com. IN A # ;ANSWER # ;AUTHORITY # ;ADDITIONAL expected_response = (b"271289050001000000000000076578616d706c6503636f6" b"d0000010001") self.service._dns_handle(self.addr, binascii.a2b_hex(payload)) sendto_mock.assert_called_once_with( binascii.a2b_hex(expected_response), self.addr)

commit_message:
Use base Angular template rather than custom template

For reasons outlined in the bug report, this patch uses the base
'angular.html' template.  This has little effect on the functionality at
this point; test by going to the Search panel and verifying that things
look right.

Change-Id: I663ebfdea6f9f9b03e24f3ca73ac3055f3a20e74
Closes-Bug: 1585658

commit_message:
Implement ViewManager list_stack_failures

This implements a method which builds a list of failed resources that would be
useful to a user to diagnose a stack failure.

Failed resources are added by recursing from the top level stack into failed
nested stack resources. A failed nested stack resource is only added to the
failed list if it contains no failed resources so that the user only sees
root-cause failed resources.

Change-Id: I78f15e8b17eda4b463074638c95655129d5a81c0
Blueprint: tripleo-manage-software-deployments
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/46/270546/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _append_failed_resources(self, failures, resources, resource_path): '''Recursively build list of failed resources''' appended = False for r in resources: if not r.resource_status.endswith('FAILED'): continue # determine if this resources is a nested stack links_rel = list([l['rel'] for l in r.links]) is_nested = 'nested' in links_rel nested_appended = False if is_nested: nested_resources = self._list_resources( r.physical_resource_id) nested_resource_path = list(resource_path) nested_resource_path.append(r.resource_name) nested_appended = self._append_failed_resources( failures, nested_resources, nested_resource_path) if not nested_appended: failures.append(models.ResourceInfo(r, resource_path)) appended = True return appended def list_stack_failures(self, stack): '''List information about FAILED stack resources. Failed resources are added by recursing from the top level stack into failed nested stack resources. A failed nested stack resource is only added to the failed list if it contains no failed resources. ''' s = self.heatclient.stacks.get(stack) if s.status != 'FAILED': return [] resources = self._list_resources(s.id) failures = [] self._append_failed_resources(failures, resources, [s.stack_name]) return failures

commit_message:
openstack overcloud failures

CLI command which prints failed resources in the overcloud to help debug
overcloud issues.

Failed resources are added by recursing from the top level stack into
failed nested stack resources. A failed nested stack resource is only
added to the failed list if it contains no failed resources so that the
user only sees root-cause failed resources.

The output is a yamlish format where the key is a dot-delimited resource
name path and the value is a dict of resource information.

Change-Id: I6621e9dc2466be8aa27e272c38f5f4dbc8d559c4
Blueprint: tripleo-manage-software-deployments
Depends-On: I78f15e8b17eda4b463074638c95655129d5a81c0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/14/271114/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Red Hat, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # import logging from cliff import command from openstackclient.i18n import _ from tripleo_common.core import view from tripleoclient import format_utils class ListOvercloudFailures(command.Command): log = logging.getLogger(__name__ + ".ListOvercloudFailures") def take_action(self, parsed_args): self.log.debug("take_action(%s)" % parsed_args) vm = view.ViewManager( self.app.client_manager.tripleoclient.orchestration, self.app.client_manager.compute) fails = vm.list_stack_failures( parsed_args.stack) format_utils.print_failures(fails, long=parsed_args.long) def get_parser(self, prog_name): parser = super(ListOvercloudFailures, self).get_parser(prog_name) parser.add_argument( '--stack', help=_("Name of overcloud stack"), default='overcloud') parser.add_argument( '--long', action='store_true', default=False, help='Show full deployment logs in output', ) return parser

commit_message:
Initial commit of zuul-worker DIB element

Now that zuulv2.5 has landed, we can start building our DIBs using the
new zuul-worker element.  As part of the jenkins clean up, we'll
eventually be removing all things jenkins from our puppet manifests.

As we move forward, we'll be using DIB to bootstrap our zuul-workers
over puppet.

Change-Id: I0e76931fdb4ca0c7445b1e72dc348f0cf03eaee5
Depends-On: Idb4ef11576671180060fb5b2b1202f9bfec5fd47
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Check that all defined entry points can be loaded

Stevedore will silently ignore an entry point that cannot be loaded so
this new test will check that all the entry points defined for the auth
plugins can be loaded.

Change-Id: I6c778e13e0f151ee6d47376277e84920678d0564
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystoneauth refs/changes/80/319980/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock import stevedore import stevedore.extension from keystoneauth1 import loading from keystoneauth1.tests.unit.loading import utils class EntryPointTests(utils.TestCase): """Simple test that will check that all entry points are loadable.""" def test_all_entry_points_are_valid(self): errors = [] def raise_exception_callback(manager, entrypoint, exc): error = ("Cannot load '%(entrypoint)s' entry_point: %(error)s'" % {"entrypoint": entrypoint, "error": exc}) errors.append(error) mgr = stevedore.ExtensionManager( namespace=loading.PLUGIN_NAMESPACE, on_load_failure_callback=raise_exception_callback ) self.assertEqual([], errors)

missing the required fields, like in the case of periodic jobs, to

commit_message:
Skip ES lookups on runs with missing metadata

This commit fixes a bug when the data returned from subunit2sql is
missing the required fields, like in the case of periodic jobs, to
use the elastic-recheck classifier. Previously it was assumed all
runs being returned from subunit2sql would have an associated change
and the metadata associated with that, but this wasn't always true.
So now it will just skip trying to do an ES lookup if all the required
fields aren't present.

Change-Id: I395656c94499f658df1dd20cafa0783e394bc382

commit_message:
Add API Change Tutorial

This change adds a tutorial for making an API change. It describes from
the specification proposal to making real code changes in keystone.

Its goal is to help new contributors to get familiar with keystone code.
It simulates the addition of a 'description' field to role entities.

Change-Id: Ie6f302939f43e78f07183abf4bc5aadb6b50ef1c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/89/302789/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. API Change Tutorial =================== This document will guide you through the process of proposing and submitting and API change in keystone. Prerequisites ------------- In order to follow this tutorial, it is assumed that you have read our `developer guide`_ and `architecture`_ documents. .. _`developer guide`: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/keystone/developing.html .. _`architecture`: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/keystone/architecture.html Proposing a change ------------------ You need to submit a specification against the `keystone-specs`_ repository and bring it up to discussion with the `keystone core team`_ for agreement. .. _`keystone-specs`: https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone-specs/ .. _`keystone core team`: https://review.openstack.org/#/admin/groups/9,members Create ~~~~~~ #. git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/keystone-specs ; #. Use the provided `template`_ ; #. Push to gerrit for review ; #. Propose agenda items to the `keystone meeting`_, and make sure someone who understands the subject can attend the meeting to answer questions. .. _`template`: https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone-specs/tree/specs/template.rst .. _`keystone meeting`: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/KeystoneMeeting Agreement ~~~~~~~~~ The `keystone core team`_ will evaluate the specification and vote on accepting it or not. If accepted, the proposal will be targeted to a release; otherwise, the specification will be abandoned. As soon as there is an agreement on the specification, the change may start rolling out. Implementing a change --------------------- In this section, let's assume that a specification proposing the addition of a `description` field to roles was accepted. In the next subsections, you will find a detailed explanation on the needed code changes to the keystone code to implementh such change. TODO(samueldmq): describe the fun part here :)

commit_message:
Specify a user-agent in Pure volume drivers

Previously we were just using the default user-agent that the python
requests module would send. With newer versions of the pure storage
python module you can now specify a custom one.

This will help to identify on the backend what requests are being
sent by the VolumeDriver vs other python scripts running against the
same array.

As part of this we will also remove support for the older version of
the python module. The newer versions are released and easily upgraded
to.

Change-Id: Icf8595843e38381c6704fd6a9c66b752f91337a5
Closes-Bug: #1579194

This patch fixes an issue where template VLUNs are left
behind during a detach.  This can happen when a volume is
exported via multiple ports to support multipath and at
detach time one of those paths becomes inactive, bad nic,
pulled cable, etc.

The 3PAR inactive VLUNs are actually templates.  When you

Change-Id: If34b76e58684138ca2acb8d38587fb30cfbd5909

commit_message:
3PAR Clean up VLUN deletion on detach

This patch fixes an issue where template VLUNs are left
behind during a detach.  This can happen when a volume is
exported via multiple ports to support multipath and at
detach time one of those paths becomes inactive, bad nic,
pulled cable, etc.

The 3PAR inactive VLUNs are actually templates.  When you
delete a template VLUN, all active VLUNs associated with
that template are also removed.  This patch deletes
template VLUNs at detach time.

Change-Id: If34b76e58684138ca2acb8d38587fb30cfbd5909
Closes-Bug: #1582922
(cherry picked from commit 9b24d615cf78ce7e8d5bac714f63845210bce6ba)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/26/318826/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 3.0.18.1 - Rework delete_vlun. Bug #1582922 (backported from Newton) VERSION = "3.0.18.1" # When deleteing VLUNs, you simply need to remove the template VLUN # and any active VLUNs will be automatically removed. The template # VLUN are marked as active: False # template VLUNs are 'active' = False if not vlun['active']: volume_vluns.append(vlun) for vlun in volume_vluns: if 'portPos' in vlun: self.client.deleteVLUN(volume_name, vlun['lun'], hostname=hostname, port=vlun['portPos']) else: self.client.deleteVLUN(volume_name, vlun['lun'], hostname=hostname)
deleted_lines: VERSION = "3.0.18" # Find all the VLUNs associated with the volume. The VLUNs will then # be split into groups based on the active status of the VLUN. If there # are active VLUNs detected a delete will be attempted on them. If # there are no active VLUNs but there are inactive VLUNs, then the # inactive VLUNs will be deleted. The inactive VLUNs are the templates # on the 3PAR backend. active_volume_vluns = [] inactive_volume_vluns = [] if vlun['active']: active_volume_vluns.append(vlun) else: inactive_volume_vluns.append(vlun) if active_volume_vluns: volume_vluns = active_volume_vluns elif inactive_volume_vluns: volume_vluns = inactive_volume_vluns removed_luns = [] for vlun in volume_vluns: if self.VLUN_TYPE_MATCHED_SET == vlun['type']: self.client.deleteVLUN(volume_name, vlun['lun'], hostname, vlun['portPos']) else: # This is HOST_SEES or a type that is not MATCHED_SET. # By deleting one VLUN, all the others should be deleted, too. if vlun['lun'] not in removed_luns: self.client.deleteVLUN(volume_name, vlun['lun'], hostname) removed_luns.append(vlun['lun'])

commit_message:
Assisted snapshot:  use Keystone Session with Nova Client

The Nova client has trouble dealing with Keystone V3 or unversioned
Keystone endpoint, when instantiated without a Keystone Session. Thus
we can't instantiate Nova client directly as cinder.compute.nova
does currently.

Keystone V3 and unversioned service catalog is the future (see [1]
and [2]) so we should adapt.

Please read comments #5, #6 and #11 of the related bug report.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/271508/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/302480/

Change-Id: Ic790955e677c5dfa47680bf619c57fba3deeee20
Related-Bug: #1522402

commit_message:
Get endpoint if os_image_url is not set

If env['OS_IMAGE_URL'] is not set then None is returned. This is then
used ignoring the endpoint_type, service_type and region_name. This
patch will use those values if the endpoint is None.

Change-Id: I76cc527b05d2be75d3dbc33123a0d71be97fe25c
Closes-bug: #1579768
(cherry picked from commit a862196cfb7f7323b1864b4c1660c39850487a64)

commit_message:
Get endpoint if os_image_url is not set

If env['OS_IMAGE_URL'] is not set then None is returned. This is then
used ignoring the endpoint_type, service_type and region_name. This
patch will use those values if the endpoint is None.

Change-Id: I76cc527b05d2be75d3dbc33123a0d71be97fe25c
Closes-bug: #1579768
(cherry picked from commit a862196cfb7f7323b1864b4c1660c39850487a64)

commit_message:
Remove deprecated tempest_lib and use tempest.lib

Since 10.0.0 release tempest-ib is deprecated now.
Cinderclient should use tempest.lib in test code
and add tempest>=11.0.0 in requirements following
global-requirements.

Closes-Bug: #1583583
Change-Id: I9d766f46eb6fff29ae9c0267a60ff2ef4bf2343e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/18/318618/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from tempest.lib.cli import base from tempest.lib.cli import output_parser from tempest.lib import exceptions
deleted_lines: from tempest_lib.cli import base from tempest_lib.cli import output_parser from tempest_lib import exceptions

commit_message:
Add support for releasenotes

Create the releasenotes directory and add the requisite
conf.py file to generate python-manilaclient's release notes.

project-config change: I522ba76263a6597026f6dd7b03ec51bb05bfb15a

Change-Id: I6b0fa6016781a252a71649a7cac85f02b0a019e8

commit_message:
Disable the netconsole service (if present)

This patch checks for the netconsole service on a host and disables the
service, if the service is installed. The service will be stopped
immediately if it is found to be running.

Documentation and release notes are included.

Closes-bug: 1584194

Change-Id: If779af67c2a66e7b56d170f1f12744aef75ff27b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-security refs/changes/45/319445/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: security_disable_netconsole: yes # v-38672

commit_message:
Docs: Update dev notes for Cat 2 controls

This patch updates the documentation for the developer notes associated
with the Cat 2 (Medium) controls applied by the security role.

Partial-bug: 1583744

Change-Id: Ic342f33942521db009185585a21208a4688f6ed3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-security refs/changes/54/318954/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The Ansible tasks will disable the ``bluetooth`` service and stop it if it is running on the system.
deleted_lines: Although neither Ubuntu 14.04 or openstack-ansible installs the ``bluetooth`` package, the Ansible tasks will disable the service and stop it if it's found to be running on the system.

commit_message:
Add a configurable sleep before IPA starts working

Some kernel modules take substantial time to initialize. For example,
with mpt2sas RAID driver inspection and deployment randomly fail
due to IPA starting before the driver finishes initialization.

As much as I hate it, the only way to guarantee that the hardware is
truely initalized is to wait for it. Apparently all hardware in Linux
is treated as hotplugged, so there is no such thing as "hardware
initialization is finished". Operators can add a sleep based on their
knowledge of their hardware.

The default behaviour remains the same.

Change-Id: I0446ae81d760dacaf31eea6ad9f9eaa098cf5e93
Partial-Bug: #1582797
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent refs/changes/45/318745/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.IntOpt('hardware_initialization_delay', default=APARAMS.get('ipa-hardware-initialization-delay', 10), help='How much time (in seconds) to wait for hardware to ' 'initialize before proceeding with any actions.'), CONF.standalone, CONF.hardware_initialization_delay).run()

commit_message:
Allow to specify node arch

This patch introduce new variable IRONIC_VM_SPECS_CPU_ARCH that
defines VM arch to create.

Change-Id: Iedf592b24952ee197207448ba36b95521a9725d7

deleted_lines: case $5 in i386) ARCH='i686' ;; amd64) ARCH='x86_64' ;; *) echo "Unsupported arch $4!" ; exit 1 ;; esac

subject: Added package references to generated UIs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-25 17:05:56.000000000', 'files': ['contrib/plugins/cloudify_plugin/murano_cloudify_plugin/cloudify_tosca_package.py', 'murano/packages/hot_package.py', 'contrib/plugins/murano_heat-translator_plugin/plugin/csar_package.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/murano/commit/1ff47503a1df6a22b576dec1552068e8b6f10edd', 'message': "Added package references to generated UIs

Generated UIs of the non-muranoPL packages (HOT, cloudify_tosca and
CSAR) reference the type of object model's object by class FQNs.
However, when these packages are uploaded to glare, their class
contents are not indexed since the client which uploads them has no
knowledge of the generated classes.

To workaround this issue it is proposed to reference objects not just
by class FQNs but to include the package FQN and the version, so the
engine does not have to rely on Glare's indexes.

Change-Id: I6175e89b68bcdfc29d33ae3616d6ecba662f2509
Partial-bug: #1565805
"}]
commit_message:
Added package references to generated UIs

Generated UIs of the non-muranoPL packages (HOT, cloudify_tosca and
CSAR) reference the type of object model's object by class FQNs.
However, when these packages are uploaded to glare, their class
contents are not indexed since the client which uploads them has no
knowledge of the generated classes.

To workaround this issue it is proposed to reference objects not just
by class FQNs but to include the package FQN and the version, so the
engine does not have to rely on Glare's indexes.

Change-Id: I6175e89b68bcdfc29d33ae3616d6ecba662f2509
Partial-bug: #1565805

commit_message:
Updates method details in monitor-driver guide

Method definitions in the monitoring driver guide
is updated to be more readable.

Also 'action' section is updated with 'heat'.

Change-Id: I4ec8e8af1c5b756c791435142ad8af9386db277e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tacker refs/changes/26/314526/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Following methods need to be overridden in the new driver: ``def get_type(self)`` This method must return the type of driver. ex: ping ``def get_name(self)`` This method must return the symbolic name of the device monitor plugin. ``def get_description(self)`` This method must return the description for the monitor driver. ``def monitor_get_config(self, plugin, context, device)`` This method must return dictionary of configuration data for the monitor driver. ``def monitor_url(self, plugin, context, device)`` This method must return the url of device to monitor. ``def monitor_call(self, device, kwargs)`` This method must either return boolean value 'True', if VNF is healthy. Otherwise it should return a event string like 'failure' or 'calls-capacity-reached' based on specific VNF health condition. More details on these event is given in below section.As mentioned above section, if the return value of monitor_call method is other than boolean value 'True', then we have to map those event to the corresponding action as described below.In this example, we have an event called 'failure'. So whenever monitor_call#. respawn #. log_and_kill #. log #. heat
deleted_lines: The methods that need to override in driver are: 1)def get_type(self) This method must return the type of driver ex: ping 2)def get_name(self) This method must return the symbolic name of the device monitor plugin 3)def get_description(self) This method must return the description for the monitor driver 4)def monitor_get_config(self, plugin, context, device) This method must return dict of monitor configuration data 5)def monitor_url(self, plugin, context, device) This method must return the url of device to monitor 6)def monitor_call(self, device, kwargs) This method must either return boolean value True if VNF is healthy or return a event string like 'failure' or 'calls-capacity-reached' for specific VNF health condition.As mentioned above, the return value of monitor_call is health status. If the return value of monitor_call is other than boolean value True, then we have to map those event to the corresponding action as described below.In this example we have an event called 'failure'. So whenever monitor_call1. respawn 2. log_and_kill 3. log

commit_message:
move most things out from the playbooks dir, and use config for release info

* move the roles, libraries and config to a top level dir
* adjust the ansible.cfg to account for the new role path
* create a config directory
  config/release  <- only for release and image_url info
  config/general_config <- everything else
* update collect-logs role path
* add ci-scripts/full-minimal.sh so that jjb will not have
to be updated after this.

Change-Id: I2e6129553bca253fa47ce56bfcbc2f244e74409e

commit_message:
Release Puppet OpenStack 7.1.0 (Liberty)

This patch adds a new release of Puppet OpenStack modules for our
Liberty branches.

All modules will be tagged 7.1.0 (7.x.x) is our Liberty versionning
except puppet-vswitch that will have 3.1.0.

Change-Id: Iaf5f160ccd8baa78c2b93bc7000e6cd5a2e59caf

subject: Fix auditd log permission bug
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-24 16:17:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-security/commit/104dff89ed4173b444848f50e5b3a71f88f96890', 'message': 'Fix auditd log permission bug

The tasks for handling auditd log permissions incorrectly set all
log files in /var/log/audit to 0400, which prevents auditd from
writing to the active log file. This prevents auditd from starting and
restarting.

The task now removes any permissions explicitly disallowed by
V-38498. Any files meeting/exceeding the STIG requirements will not be
modified.

This is a manual backport of I1bb2b91ae8a78b1f0304bd4ce0f9a774d65245bd
from master.

Closes-bug: 1584942

Change-Id: I1bb2b91ae8a78b1f0304bd4ce0f9a774d65245bd
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-05-25 14:22:48.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/developer-notes/V-38498.rst', 'releasenotes/notes/fix-audit-log-permission-bug-81a772e2e6d0a5b3.yaml', 'tasks/auditd.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-security/commit/00ad8d3b571974d17028c84823ca62647a0e4b34', 'message': 'Fix auditd log permission bug

The tasks for handling auditd log permissions incorrectly set all
log files in /var/log/audit to 0400, which prevents auditd from
writing to the active log file. This prevents auditd from starting and
restarting.

The task now removes any permissions explicitly disallowed by
V-38498. Any files meeting/exceeding the STIG requirements will not be
modified.

commit_message:
Fix auditd log permission bug

The tasks for handling auditd log permissions incorrectly set all
log files in /var/log/audit to 0400, which prevents auditd from
writing to the active log file. This prevents auditd from starting and
restarting.

The task now removes any permissions explicitly disallowed by
V-38498. Any files meeting/exceeding the STIG requirements will not be
modified.

This is a manual backport of I1bb2b91ae8a78b1f0304bd4ce0f9a774d65245bd
from master.

Closes-bug: 1584942

Change-Id: I1bb2b91ae8a78b1f0304bd4ce0f9a774d65245bd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-security refs/changes/59/320559/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # On most systems, the active log file is 0600 and the older logs are 0400. # This task ensures that all logs meet or exceed the STIG requirement. mode: "u-x,g-wx,o-rwx" with_items: "{{ v38498_result.stdout_lines | default([]) }}" when: auditd_log_dir.stat.exists | bool
deleted_lines: # Ubuntu 14.04 sets these to 0400 by default, so we will stick with that since # it exceeds the STIG's requirements. mode: 0400 with_items: v38498_result.stdout_lines when: v_38498_result is defined

commit_message:
Added package references to generated UIs

Generated UIs of the non-muranoPL packages (HOT, cloudify_tosca and
CSAR) reference the type of object model's object by class FQNs.
However, when these packages are uploaded to glare, their class
contents are not indexed since the client which uploads them has no
knowledge of the generated classes.

To workaround this issue it is proposed to reference objects not just
by class FQNs but to include the package FQN and the version, so the
engine does not have to rely on Glare's indexes.

Change-Id: I6175e89b68bcdfc29d33ae3616d6ecba662f2509
Partial-bug: #1565805

commit_message:
Support TCP connection pipelining

Change-Id: I8857118a785a80a5bc67fa75a4d03569e50cc9c4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/64/310264/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: _TCP_RECV_MAX_SIZE = 65535 # handle a new TCP connection # Dispatch a thread to handle the connection self.tg.add_thread(self._dns_handle_tcp_conn, addr, client) def _dns_handle_tcp_conn(self, addr, client): """ Handle a DNS Query over TCP. Multiple queries can be pipelined though the same TCP connection but they will be processed sequentially. See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-dnsop-5966bis-03 Raises no exception: it's to be run in an eventlet green thread :param addr: Tuple of the client's (IP addr, Port) :type addr: tupple :param client: Client socket :type client: socket :raises: None """ host, port = addr try: # The whole loop lives in a try/except block. On exceptions, the # connection is closed: there would be little chance to save save # the connection after a struct error, a socket error. while True: # Decode the first 2 bytes containing the query length expected_length_raw = client.recv(2) (expected_length, ) = struct.unpack('!H', expected_length_raw) # Keep receiving data until we've got all the data we expect # The buffer contains only one query at a time buf = "" while len(buf) < expected_length: recv_size = min(expected_length - len(buf), self._TCP_RECV_MAX_SIZE) data = client.recv(recv_size) if not data: break buf += data query = buf # Call into the DNS Application itself with payload and addr for response in self._dns_application( {'payload': query, 'addr': addr}): # Send back a response only if present if response is None: continue # Handle TCP Responses msg_length = len(response) tcp_response = struct.pack("!H", msg_length) + response client.sendall(tcp_response) except socket.timeout: LOG.info(_LI("TCP Timeout from: %(host)s:%(port)d"), {'host': host, 'port': port}) except socket.error as e: errname = errno.errorcode[e.args[0]] LOG.warning(_LW("Socket error %(err)s from: %(host)s:%(port)d"), {'host': host, 'port': port, 'err': errname}) except struct.error: LOG.warning(_LW("Invalid packet from: %(host)s:%(port)d"), {'host': host, 'port': port}) except Exception: LOG.exception(_LE("Unknown exception handling TCP request " "from: %(host)s:%(port)d"), {'host': host, 'port': port}) finally: client.close()
deleted_lines: # Prepare a variable for the payload to be buffered payload = "" # Receive the first 2 bytes containing the payload length expected_length_raw = client.recv(2) (expected_length, ) = struct.unpack('!H', expected_length_raw) # Keep receiving data until we've got all the data we expect while len(payload) < expected_length: data = client.recv(65535) if not data: break payload += data except struct.error: client.close() LOG.warning(_LW("Invalid packet from: %(host)s:%(port)d") % {'host': addr[0], 'port': addr[1]}) else: # Dispatch a thread to handle the query self.tg.add_thread(self._dns_handle, addr, payload, client=client)

commit_message:
Deprecate advertise_mtu option

Now that we advertise MTU via DHCP and RA by default, there is no reason
to keep the option available for configuration. Other agents/plugins are
also encouraged to advertise MTU values to instances by their own means.

DocImpact: mark the advertise_mtu option as deprecated as of Newton.

Closes-Bug: 1576000
Change-Id: Ibf7d60dfc57bec090f16d909c050c09e7cfd9352
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/48/310448/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- deprecations: - The 'advertise_mtu' option is deprecated and will be removed in next releases. DHCP and L3 agents will continue advertising MTU values to instances by their own means. Plugins are also encouraged to advertise to instances.

commit_message:
Grammar: requires -> required

"requires" sort of makes sense in the variable name ("keystone requires
these pip packages), but as a task name, the task is "installing the
required pip packages." #ultranit

commit_message:
Remove k8s pods, rcs, svc and container API calls

Magnum supports multiple COEs however it contains APIs that only work
with Kubernetes. We will allow additional API extensions for specific
bay drivers to allow access to the k8s APIs through Magnum. This will
allow us to support multiple COEs without having to compromise the
container API to the lowest common denominator between COEs.

Change-Id: Ic6927f77f413f5202a3dd160ff809c7ec057d3b5

deleted_lines: # Copyright 2015 NEC Corporation. All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import os.path from magnumclient.common import utils as magnum_utils from magnumclient.openstack.common import cliutils as utils def _show_coe_service(service): utils.print_dict(service._info) @utils.arg('--bay', required=True, metavar='<bay>', help="UUID or Name of Bay") def do_coe_service_list(cs, args): """Print a list of coe services.""" services = cs.services.list(args.bay) columns = ('uuid', 'name', 'bay_uuid') utils.print_list(services, columns, {'versions': magnum_utils.print_list_field('versions')}) @utils.arg('--manifest-url', metavar='<manifest-url>', help='Name/URL of the service file to use for creating services.') @utils.arg('--manifest', metavar='<manifest>', help='File path of the service file to use for creating services.') @utils.arg('--bay', required=True, metavar='<bay>', help='Id or name of the bay.') def do_coe_service_create(cs, args): """Create a coe service.""" bay = cs.bays.get(args.bay) if bay.status not in ['CREATE_COMPLETE', 'UPDATE_COMPLETE']: print('Bay status for %s is: %s. We can not create a service in bay ' 'until the status is CREATE_COMPLETE or UPDATE_COMPLETE.' % (args.bay, bay.status)) return opts = {} opts['manifest_url'] = args.manifest_url opts['bay_uuid'] = bay.uuid if args.manifest is not None and os.path.isfile(args.manifest): with open(args.manifest, 'r') as f: opts['manifest'] = f.read() service = cs.services.create(**opts) _show_coe_service(service) @utils.arg('services', metavar='<services>', help="UUID or name of service") @utils.arg('--bay', required=True, metavar='<bay>', help="UUID or Name of Bay") @utils.arg( 'op', metavar='<op>', choices=['add', 'replace', 'remove'], help="Operations: 'add', 'replace' or 'remove'") @utils.arg( 'attributes', metavar='<path=value>', nargs='+', action='append', default=[], help="Attributes to add/replace or remove " "(only PATH is necessary on remove)") def do_coe_service_update(cs, args): """Update information about the given coe service.""" patch = magnum_utils.args_array_to_patch(args.op, args.attributes[0]) p = patch[0] if p['path'] == '/manifest' and os.path.isfile(p['value']): with open(p['value'], 'r') as f: p['value'] = f.read() service = cs.services.update(args.services, args.bay, patch) _show_coe_service(service) @utils.arg('services', metavar='<services>', nargs='+', help='ID or name of the service to delete.') @utils.arg('--bay', required=True, metavar='<bay>', help="UUID or Name of Bay") def do_coe_service_delete(cs, args): """Delete specified coe service.""" for service in args.services: try: cs.services.delete(service, args.bay) except Exception as e: print("Delete for service %(service)s failed: %(e)s" % {'service': service, 'e': e}) @utils.arg('services', metavar='<services>', help='ID or name of the service to show.') @utils.arg('--bay', required=True, metavar='<bay>', help="UUID or Name of Bay") def do_coe_service_show(cs, args): """Show details about the given coe service.""" service = cs.services.get(args.services, args.bay) _show_coe_service(service)

commit_message:
Make the ssh driver work on headless VirtualBox machines

On a workstation where an X display might not currently be running
or a workstation where someone else is logged on the graphical
desktop this small change helps get things working for using
VirtualBox as the hypervisor. Use VirtualBox 3.2 or above
for headless mode support.

This patch also ensures that set_boot_device() always works by powering
off the VM before setting the device. VirtualBox does not allow boot
device to be set while the machine is on.

Closes-Bug: 1561624

Change-Id: If8d989cc3964e849544b139959b329a3fd05d451

commit_message:
Remove APIRouter of legacy v2 API code

This patch removes the APIRouter because there is not any code
which uses the APIRouter. In addition, this patch update the
corresponding reno for explaining actual way for api-paste.ini.

Partially implements blueprint remove-legacy-v2-api-code

Change-Id: I136eb6ce7478f9ff692ebcbe1b14aa76222826bf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/02/313902/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: from nova.api.openstack.compute.legacy_v2 import consoles as v2_consoles from nova.api.openstack.compute.legacy_v2 import extensions as v2_extensions from nova.api.openstack.compute.legacy_v2 import flavors as v2_flavors from nova.api.openstack.compute.legacy_v2 import image_metadata \ as v2_image_metadata from nova.api.openstack.compute.legacy_v2 import images as v2_images from nova.api.openstack.compute.legacy_v2 import ips as v2_ips from nova.api.openstack.compute.legacy_v2 import limits as v2_limits from nova.api.openstack.compute.legacy_v2 import server_metadata \ as v2_server_metadata from nova.api.openstack.compute.legacy_v2 import servers as v2_servers from nova.api.openstack.compute.legacy_v2 import versions \ as legacy_v2_versions from nova.i18n import _LWclass APIRouter(nova.api.openstack.APIRouter): """Routes requests on the OpenStack API to the appropriate controller and method. """ ExtensionManager = v2_extensions.ExtensionManager def __init__(self, ext_mgr=None, init_only=None): LOG.warning(_LW( "Deprecated: Starting with the Liberty release, the v2 API was " "already deprecated and the v2.1 API is set as the default. Nova " "also supports v2.1 API legacy v2 compatible mode for switching " "to v2.1 API smoothly. For more information on how to configure " "v2.1 API and legacy v2 compatible mode, please refer Nova " "api-paste.ini sample file.")) super(APIRouter, self).__init__(ext_mgr=ext_mgr, init_only=init_only) def _setup_routes(self, mapper, ext_mgr, init_only): if init_only is None or 'versions' in init_only: self.resources['versions'] = legacy_v2_versions.create_resource() mapper.connect("versions", "/", controller=self.resources['versions'], action='show', conditions={"method": ['GET']}) mapper.redirect("", "/") if init_only is None or 'consoles' in init_only: self.resources['consoles'] = v2_consoles.create_resource() mapper.resource("console", "consoles", controller=self.resources['consoles'], parent_resource=dict(member_name='server', collection_name='servers')) if init_only is None or 'consoles' in init_only or \ 'servers' in init_only or 'ips' in init_only: self.resources['servers'] = v2_servers.create_resource(ext_mgr) mapper.resource("server", "servers", controller=self.resources['servers'], collection={'detail': 'GET'}, member={'action': 'POST'}) if init_only is None or 'ips' in init_only: self.resources['ips'] = v2_ips.create_resource() mapper.resource("ip", "ips", controller=self.resources['ips'], parent_resource=dict(member_name='server', collection_name='servers')) if init_only is None or 'images' in init_only: self.resources['images'] = v2_images.create_resource() mapper.resource("image", "images", controller=self.resources['images'], collection={'detail': 'GET'}) if init_only is None or 'limits' in init_only: self.resources['limits'] = v2_limits.create_resource() mapper.resource("limit", "limits", controller=self.resources['limits']) if init_only is None or 'flavors' in init_only: self.resources['flavors'] = v2_flavors.create_resource() mapper.resource("flavor", "flavors", controller=self.resources['flavors'], collection={'detail': 'GET'}, member={'action': 'POST'}) if init_only is None or 'image_metadata' in init_only: v2immeta = v2_image_metadata self.resources['image_metadata'] = v2immeta.create_resource() image_metadata_controller = self.resources['image_metadata'] mapper.resource("image_meta", "metadata", controller=image_metadata_controller, parent_resource=dict(member_name='image', collection_name='images')) mapper.connect("metadata", "/{project_id}/images/{image_id}/metadata", controller=image_metadata_controller, action='update_all', conditions={"method": ['PUT']}) if init_only is None or 'server_metadata' in init_only: self.resources['server_metadata'] = \ v2_server_metadata.create_resource() server_metadata_controller = self.resources['server_metadata'] mapper.resource("server_meta", "metadata", controller=server_metadata_controller, parent_resource=dict(member_name='server', collection_name='servers')) mapper.connect("metadata", "/{project_id}/servers/{server_id}/metadata", controller=server_metadata_controller, action='update_all', conditions={"method": ['PUT']})

commit_message:
Searchlight version of hz-expand-detail

Unfortunately, upstream has modified hz-expand-detail to *require*
that it be used only as part of hz-table. This otherwise convenient
utility locks searchlight-ui into using hz-table and smart table
where it doesn't really want to.

See: https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+bug/1580809

This change paves the way for a follow-on that removes the use of
smart table.

Change-Id: Iea3dd2007f642b68e91523bc0838ea7b5836bf12
Implements: blueprint data-binding-over-events

added_lines: sl-expand-detail

Closes-Bug: #1579900

commit_message:
Unsupported module driver not logged correctly

If an invalid module driver is found, the method is erroneously
printed out instead of the actual 'type.'  This is due
to missing parenthesis in the logging call.

This has been fixed.

Change-Id: I6fb23b3dbbec98de9ee1e2731bcfc56ab3c0ca42
Closes-Bug: #1579900
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/89/314289/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - An invalid module driver is now logged correctly. Bug 1579900
